authors: C.W. Heyl
abstract: This paper descriptionbes techniques for ageing free-living juvenile laughing doves Streptopelia senegalensis and Cape turtle doves S. capicola, and calculation of their breeding seasons from primary moult data collected during a mark-recapture study.

title: The status of cranes (Aves: Gruidae) in the Orange Free State
authors: J. N. Geldenhuys
abstract: The wattled crane Grus carunculatus is rare and no longer breeds in the Orange Free State, the breeding range of the crowned crane Balearica regulorum has decreased to a small area in the north-east and the blue crane Anthropoides paradisea is widespread and abundant, and breeds throughout the province. No evidence of migration was found in the three species. Flocks of crowned and blue cranes were frequently recorded in a variety of cultivated fields. The occurrences of perennial vleis, together with a relatively low level of human disturbance, are suggested reasons for the survival of the wattled and crowned cranes in the north-east. Draining of the larger vleis is considered a major threat to the vlei ecosystems and the survival of the wattled and crowned cranes in the Orange Free State.

title: Dynamics of a migratory animal population
authors: John Hearne; J.W. Swart
abstract: A system dynamics model of the reedbuck population in the Underberg district is formulated. The model is used to investigate the effects of different harvesting strategies on the population structure and to examine the role played by migration in maintaining a stable population size. Simulations indicate that a recently proposed harvesting strategy for the region might endanger the population if generally implemented.

title: A range-finder sight for use with capture guns
authors: C.L. Bell; Van Rooyen

title: Reactions of visitors to four South African nature reserve camps toward charging for facilities and measures on a user-pays basis that incorporates social costs.
authors: Guy Preston; H. Campbell
abstract:
Preston, Fuggle & Siegfried (1991) suggested measures by which authorities can make nature reserve visitors more circumspect in their consumption of resources, arguing that the measures have both practical conservation and interpretive value. A survey of 800 adult (over 18 year old) visitors to four South African nature reserve camps was undertaken to establish reaction to these proposed measures. The camps were selected to represent a broad spectrum of visitor profiles, and a 94% response rate was achieved. Widespread support for a user-pays approach to resource utilization was found. However, specific measures to adopt the user-paysapproach to control the use of electricity and water by visitors met with greater ambivalence. Nevertheless, there would appear to be sufficient support for most of the user-pays measures to warrant their implementation on a trial basis. There would also appear to be sufficient support for reserve authorities to test the effect of incorporating social costs as private costs, where practicable.
Preston, Fuggle & Siegfried (1991) het maatreels voorgestel waarvolgens owerhede besoekers aan natuurreservate meer omsigtig kan maak m.b.t. hulle verbruik van hulpbronne, en redeneer dat die maatreels beide praktiese bewarings- en verklarende waarde het. 'n Meningsopname onder 800 volwasse (g 18 jaar oud) besoekers aan vier Suid-Afrikaanse natuurreservaatkampe is onderneem om die reaksie op die voorgestelde maatreels vas te stel. Die kampe is gekies om 'n wye spektrum van besoekersprofiele te verteenwoordig en 'n reaksiekoers van 94% is bereik. Wye ondersteuning is vir 'n 'verbuiker-betaal'-benadering tot hulpbronverbruik gevind. Spesifieke maatreels m.b.t. die aanneming van die 'verbruiker-betaal'-benadering om die elektrisiteits- en waterverbruik van besoekers te kontroleer, is egter met groter teenstrydigheid ontvang. Dit wil nietemin voorkom dat daar voldoende steun vir die meeste van die 'verbruiker-betaal'-maatstawwe is om die implementering daarvan op 'n proefbasis te regverdig. Dit wil ook voorkom asof daar voldoende steun is vir reservaatowerhede om, in gevalle waar dit uitvoerbaar is, die invloed van die insluiting van sosiale kostes as privaatkostes te toets.

title: Aspects of reproduction in mountain reedbuck from Rolfontein Nature Reserve
authors: Ducheyne Els
abstract:
One hundred and thirty-one mountain reedbuck Redunca fulvorufula of varying ages were collected during April 1981. The corpus luteum maintained a large size (7,4 to 8,0 mm; n = 19) throughout pregnancy. The amygdaloidal ovary showed a preponderance for ovulation to occur from the left ovary, while implantation only occurred in the right uterine horn. Most females conceived for the first time when 12 to 16 months of age, while males reached sexual maturity at about 27 months. A reproductive rate close to 90% seems likely for the studied population.
Material van 131 rooiribbokke Redunca fulvorufula van verskillende ouderdomme is gedurende April 1981 versamel. Die corpus luteum behou 'n grootte van 7,4 - 8,0 mm (n = 19) dwarsdeur swangerskap. Die amandelvormige ovarium vertoon 'n hoer voorkeur vir ovulasie vanaf die linker ovarium terwyl implantasie slegs in die regter uterushoring voorkom. Meeste ooie word waarskynlik vir die eerste keer bevrug op 'n ouderdom van 12 tot 16 maande terwyl ramme geslagtelike rypheid bereik nader aan 'n ouderdom van ongeveer 27 maande. 'n Voorplantingstempo van digby 90% blyk moontlik te wees vir die bestudeerde populasie.

title: First record of ciliated protozoan endocommensals in the gut of bush pig : : short communication
authors: W. van Hoven; F. M. C. Gilchrist
abstract:
Seven species of holotrich protozoan endocommensals (Holophryoides ovalis, Blepharosphaera intestinalis, B. ellipsoidalis, Didesmis ovalis, D. quadrata, Blespharoprosthium pireum, Paraisotricha colpoidea) were found in the hindgut of bushpigs Potamochoerus porcus, in the eastern and southern Cape Province, South Africa. They were similar to those reported present in the hindgut of other herbivorous mammals. No potentially pathogenic Balantidium coli, commonly occurring in the hindgut of domestic pigs Sus scrofa, were seen.
Sewe holotrige endokommensaliste protosoa-spesies (Holophryoides ovalis, Blepharosphaera intestinalis, B. ellipsoidalis, Didesmis ovalis, D. quadrata, Blespharoprosthium pireum, Paraisotricha colpoidea) is gevind in die dikderm van bosvarke Potamochoerus porcus, in die Oos- en Suid-Kaap, Suid-Afrika. Die spesies stem ooreen met die wat reeds in die dikderm van ander plantvretende soogdiere aangeteken is. Geen van die potensieel patogeniese Balantidium coli wat algemeen in die dikderm van die gedomestikeerde vark Sus scrofa voorkom, is gevind nie.

title: Chemical attributes of seeds of some economically important Karoo plants
authors: Graham I. H. Kerley; T. Erasmus
abstract:
Seed mass and energy, moisture, protein, polyphenol, ash, lipid and silica contents of the seeds of 11 plant species from the semi-arid Karoo were estimated. Cell contents, soluble ash and soluble carbohydrates contents of the seeds were derived from these values. The energy contents of these seeds, although low, are representative of seeds of arid and semi-arid plants. Protein levels tended to be below the minimum requirement for omnivorous mammals. Problems in relating the chemical attributes of seeds and their nutiritional value to granivores are discussed.
Saadmassas asook energie-, vog-, proteien-, polifenole-, as-, vet-, en silika-inhoud van die sade van 11 plantspesies van die halfdor Karoo is beraam. Selinhoud, oplosbare as- en oplosbare koolhidraatinhoud van die sade is afgelei vanaf hierdie waardes. Die energie-inhoud van die sade, hoewel laag, is verteenwoordigend van sade van dor en halfdor plante. Proteienvlakke neig om laer te wees as die minimum benodigdhede vir omnivorige soogdiere. Probleme met die vergelyking van die chemiese saamstelling van sade en die voedingswaarde vir saadvretende diere word bespreek.

title: Temporal and spatial variation in community indices of waterbirds at a coastal wetland, southern Cape Province
authors: A.F. Boshoff; S. Piper
abstract:
Waterbirds were counted monthly, between 1980 and 1984, at the six waterbodies comprising the Wilderness-Sedgefield Lakes Complex, southern Cape Province. Certain indices were calculated for each month at each waterbody and the maximum values were as follows : number of species - 47; diversity (Shannon index) - 2,8; density - 35,1 birds / ha; biomass - 29 kg / ha. The six waterbodies were ranked, from highest to lowest, according to the mean values for five indices : two specific waterbodies were usually first or second, and a further two were usually fifth or sixth. The rankings reflected the major habitat differences between the waterbodies. Marked temporal variation in certain indices was attributed to two major environmental events, namely, a temporary dieback of submerged aquatic macrophytes and a series of major floods. Overall, there was a negative relationship between the indices and water level.
Watervoels is tussen 1980 en 1984 op 'n maandelikse basis by die ses waterliggame van die Wilderness-Sedgefield Merekompleks, suidelike Kaapprovinsie, getel. Sekere indekse is maandeliks vir elke waterliggaam bereken en die maksimum waardes was soos volg : getal spesies - 47; diversiteit (Shannon indeks) - 2,8; digtheid - 35,1 voels / ha; biomassa - 29 kg / ha. Die ses waterliggame is vanaf die hoogste tot die laagste gemiddelde waardes vir vyf indekse georden en dieselfde twee waterliggame was gewoonlik eerste of tweede, terwyl twee ander gewoonlik vyfde of sesde was. Die ordening het die belangrikste habitatverskilletussen die waterliggame weerspieel. Opvallende variasie van sekere indekse, oor tyd, word aan twee belangrike omgewingsgebeure toegeskryf, naamlik, 'n tydelike afname van onderwaterse akwatiese makrofiete en 'n reeks vloede. In geheel was daar 'n negatiewe verwantskap tussen die indekse en watervlakke.

title: Intra-seasonal variation in clutch size of the Cape shoveller in the south-western Cape : short communication
authors: Adrian J. Armstrong; W. R. Siegfried
abstract:
Change in the distribution of sizes of first-laid clutches of the Cape shoveller Anas smithii as the breeding season progresses was investigated in one local geographical area. Data from 22 discrete years were pooled. The distribution of clutch sizes was not significantly different between months of hatching. This finding contrasts the results for all northern hemisphere Anas species investigated.
Die verandering in die grootte-verspreiding van eerste broeisels van die Kaapse slopeend Anas smithii in die loop van die broeiseisoen is ondersoek vir een plaaslike geografiese area. Data van 22 jare is saamgevoeg. Die verspreiding van broeiselgrootte het nie beduidend verskil tussen uitbroeimaande nie. Hierdie bevindinge is in teenstelling met resultate van Anas spesies wat in die noordelike-halfrond bestudeer is.

title: Organochlorine pesticide residues and PCBs in otter scats from Natal : short communication
authors: C.F. Mason; D.T. Rowe-Rowe
abstract:
Organochlorine pesticide residues and PCBs were measured in scat samples of Cape clawless otter Aonyx capensis, spotted-necked otter Lutra maculicollis and water mongoose Atilax paludinosus from four localities in Natal. DOE and PCBs occurred in all samples, dieldrin in all but one. Trace amounts of o,p-DDD and o,p-DDT were present but lindane was not detected. Scats of A. capensis contained higher concentrations of contaminants than those of the two other species. Overall levels of contamination were low and unlikely to pose a threat to otter populations at the localities studied.
Organochloorplaagdoder-residu's en PCB-verbindings is gemeet in die faeces van die groototter Aonyx capensis, kleinotter Lutra maculicollis en kommetjiegatmuishond Atilax paludinosus afkomstig van vier lokaliteite in Natal. DOE en PCB-verbindings was teenwoordig in alle monsters, en dieldrin in een. Baie klein hoeveelhede van o,p-DDD en o,p-DOT was teenwoordig, maar lindaan is nie opgemerk nie. Die mismonsters van die groototter het hoer konsentrasies van kontaminasie bevat as die van die ander twee species. In die geheel was die vlakke van kontaminasie laag en dit is onwaarskynlik dat die otterbevolkings by die lokaliteite in hierdie studie deur bogenoemde middels bedreig word.

title: The influence of farmland on eland in the Natal Drakensburg
authors: Alex Melton; D.A. Snyman
abstract: During spring and summer, most eland, Taurotragus oryx, initially marked on farmland, occurred in the higher conservation areas up to 2400 m and had a mean group size of 44 (SO = 45). During winter these eland associated in smaller groups and preferred lower elevations, including farmland down to 1550 m. Many results presented are equivalent to those of previous studies in Giant's Castle Game Reserve, but some differences are noted and discussed. Movement and area use analyses show that management of eland on agricultural land cannot be separated from conservation of the species over the whole Drakensberg range.

title: Accumulation of nickel in three freshwater crab populations
authors: V.E. Steenkamp; H.H. Du Preez; H. J. Schoonbee; Anat Shafir
abstract: An investigation was made into the nickel concentrations of the water and sediments of the Natalspruit and Bronkhorstspruit Rivers (Gauteng) and Nooitgedacht Dam (North West Province), as well as nickel concentrations in tissues of the freshwater crab Potamonautes warreni from these three water systems. Water nickel concentrations were relatively constant, while large fluctuations were detected in the sediment nickel concentrations. The highest water and sediment nickel concentrations were measured at the Natalspruit River. The highest mean tissue concentration of nickel in P. warreni sampled from the three aquatic systems was detected in the carapace, indicating that this tissue might be used as a sink for nickel, for disposing of excessive amounts during the moult-cycle. No seasonal variation was detected. Sex also does not seem to be a variation factor in the bioaccumulation of nickel except in the mature gonads. P. warreni collected from the three different sampling sites showed a general increase in tissue nickel concentrations with a decrease in size. Significant correlations were observed between the midgut gland nickel concentrations and the concentration of this metal in the water (r = 0,63) and sediment (r = 0,77), as well as between the muscle nickel concentration and the water and sediment nickel concentrations (r = 0,63 and r = 0,77, respectively). These phenomena, as well as the fact that P. warreni is able to accumulate relatively high levels of nickel in various tissues, suggest that this freshwater crab is a potential indicator of nickel pollution in aquatic ecosystems.

title: Effective methods of trapping and marking rock hyrax
authors: M.R. Fourie; Louise Perrin
abstract: A descriptionption of an effective cage trap is given and the live capture and marking of hyrax are discussed. Ear tagging and freeze branding were used to mark hyrax and are assessed critically. Prevention of infection in the ears of tagged hyrax, resulted in long retention times of the tags

title: Rearing of artificially spawned southern mullet
authors: A.H. Bok
abstract: The incubation of artificially fertilized southern mullet eggs and attempts at rearing the free embryos and larvae to 50 days are descriptionbed. Although fertilization and hatching success rates of up to 80% were achieved, subsequent mortalities of the delicate larvae were high. The supply of suitable live food organisms at the optimum densities for the larvae proved problematic. Two batches of larvae died within seven days of hatching while a third showed 0,2% (100 larvae) survival to 50 days. Two critical periods associated with high larval mortality were found on the 3rd-5th and 8th-12th days after hatching. The rotifer, Brachionus plicatilis, appeared suitable as first food for the larvae. Possible means of improving larval survival are outlined.

title: Diets of coastal and inland-dwelling water mongoose: Short communication
authors: J. A. Louw; C.J. Nel
abstract: Diets of water mongoose Atilax paludinosus living along the coast and inland, as derived from faecal analyses, were compared. The most important prey items of coastal mongoose were amphipods and the common shore crab Cyclograpsus punctatus. Mongoose along two rivers inland from the coast preyed heavily on frogs, rodents and birds, or crabs and fish, respectively.

title: The lise of Zoletil for the immobilization of spotted hyaenas: Short communication
authors: A. S. van Jaarsveld
abstract: The use of Zoletil for the chemical immobilization of spotted hyaenas Crocuta crocuta is descriptionbed. A dose of 250 mg/individual ca 4 mg/kg) was found effective for the immobilization of wild adult spotted hyaenas, whereas this dosage could be reduced to 2 mg/kg for captive individuals. The drug was used on hyaenas of a wide range of ages and on females in an advanced stage of pregnancy without any adverse effects.

title: Population status and distribution of puku in a changing riverfront habitat in northern Botswana : research article
authors: F. M. Dipotso; Christina Skarpe
abstract:
Studies on the population status, distribution, and behaviour of puku ( Kobus vardoni ) on the 
floodplains along the Chobe river front were carried out from April 2001 to February 2003. 
The population of puku was believed to be in decline since the last census in 1965-1967, 
following profound habitat changes caused by an increase in elephants and other large 
herbivores in the area. Our study, however, showed a strong increase in numbers of puku 
compared to the 1960s. Concentration of the population had, however, shifted eastwards, 
possibly as a result of direct human disturbance in the western part of the riverfront. Puku 
mainly utilized floodplain habitat (91% of sightings). The most common observation was of 
breeding herds (36%) followed by adult males (26%). Calving took place year round though 
with a peak in March/April. Although puku have increased in numbers along the Chobe River 
the population is small and isolated, andmust be considered vulnerable. Apparently suitable 
habitats in the area, which today are little used by puku due to human disturbance, could 
again become important and allowthe population to increase further, if disturbance could be 
reduced.

title: Foraging habits of the Nile rat, Arvicanthis niloticus, in the Guinea Savanna of Nigeria : research article
authors: T.J. Orsar; E.A. Agbelusi
abstract:
Research on habitat utilization by the Nile rat ( Arvicanthis niloticus )was carried out in the 
Guinea Savanna of Nigeria to determine food preference, parts of plant utilized as sources of 
food and their proximate composition. Indirect field observations as well as direct ex situ 
methods of observation were made. A vegetation analysis of preferred habitat was also 
carried out to determine the floral composition. A proximate analysis of some of the 
preferred forage species and their parts was carried out as well. Data obtained from the 
proximate composition of forage species were subjected to statistical analysis. The result of 
the vegetation analysis revealed that Imperata cylindrical/Ig (speargrass) and Hyparrhenia 
dissolutal/Ig (roofing grass, thatching grass) were the dominant grass species while Dactyloctenium aegyptiuml/Ig (cowfoot-grass) and Andropogon gayanusl/Ig (gambagrass) were 
fairly abundant. The field observations also revealed that the Nile rat preferred young shoots 
of Andropogon gayanus, Panicum maximuml/Ig (guineagrass), Hyparrhenia dissolutal/Ig and 
inflorescence of Dactyloctenium aegyptium. Ex situl/Ig observations revealed that roots 
and shoot-meristem of Andropogon gayanusl/Ig and Hyparrhenia dissolutal/Ig were eaten in 
preference to other parts of the plant. Proximate composition showed that crude protein 
content was inversely related to fibre level. Inner shoot-meristem (IM) of these preferred 
forage species contained the highest ( P < 0.05) level of crude protein. Roots were also 
selected despite their lower protein and high fibre content.

title: An assessment of the large mammal component of the proposed wildlife sanctuary site in Maasai Kuku Group Ranch near Amboseli, Kenya : research article
authors: Moses Makonjio Okello
abstract:
Many pastoralcommunities that share rangelands with wildlife are looking for direct benefits 
from wildlife resources found on their land. In the group ranches around Amboseli National 
Park, the Maasai community is hoping that wildlife-based ecotourism ventures will earn 
them direct revenue. However, for ecotourism, prerequisites such as tourist attractions 
(especially large mammals), community willingness and support, tourist and tourism investor 
opinions, support of conservation stakeholders, and economic viability need to be 
assessed. This paper focused on the large mammal resources of the proposed Kuku Community 
Conservation Area (KCCA) and compared them to surrounding existing protected 
areas. This includes a preliminary survey of large mammal density and distribution on the 
group ranch; identification of a potential location of the sanctuary based on preliminary findings; 
and estimates of large mammal density and diversity in comparison with protected 
sites. Point counts, road transects and foot transects were used to count the large mammal 
species. The proposed KCCA and its Corridor were comparable in density of wildlife to 
Amboseli Park and Kimana Community Wildlife Sanctuary (KCWS) despite also supporting 
high densities of livestock and human settlement. Further, the proposed sites had consistently 
higher large mammal species diversity than Amboseli Park. There were large mammals 
of interest to tourists, including members of tourism's 'big five', making the selected 
location suitable for establishment of a wildlife sanctuary. The proximity to these famous 
parks, the presence of attractive physical features (such as Mt Kilimanjaro and Chyulu Hills) 
and Maasai culture makes the proposed KCCA viable for ecotourism. The model of the 
proposed KCCA should incorporate local access to resources (such as water, pasture and 
plant resources) during times of scarcity and therefore make it a multiple-use conservation 
area with critical resources for pastoralism as well as supporting ecotourism.

title: Survey of the status and management of sympatric bushbuck and nyala in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa : research article
authors: Colleen T. Downs; Gregory D. Coates
abstract: Status and management of sympatric bushbuck and nyala in KwaZulu-Natal was investigated by means of a questionnaire survey. From opinions of landowners and reserve managers, status of bushbuck populations sharing a sympatric relationship with nyala in KwaZulu-Natal (KZN) appeared to be stable to declining, whereas nyala population status was increasing. This trend was suggested to be a result of competition for resources between the two species. Northern KZN recorded a higher frequency of this trend (57.7%, n = 26) compared to the Midlands (35.7%, n = 14), as did Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife Reserves (85.7%, n = 7) compared to privately owned properties (42.4%, n = 33). Very little species-specific management for nyala and bushbuck occurred on properties that participated in the present survey. Only 67% of properties ( n = 40) had population estimates for these species and most properties indicated that these estimates were vague. Nyala were primarily controlled by hunting (34.7%, n = 40), particularly in the Midlands, (63. 2%, n = 14), and live sales (34.7%, n = 40), particularly in northern KZN (40%, lIgnl/Ig = 26). In the Midlands 50% of properties regulated bushbuck numbers by hunting, 12.5% by live capture, and 37.5% indicated that they did not need to take animals off as no population excess occurred. This is in contrast to only 3.8% of properties in northern KZN which regulated bushbuck abundance by hunting, 11.5% by live capture, and 65.5% which did not need to regulate bushbuck abundance because numbers of this species were too low.

title: Caring for Natural Rangelands, Ken Coetzee : book review
authors: Justin du Toit
abstract:
Extracted from text ... Book review 
Caring for Natural Rangelandsby Ken Coetzee. 
University of KwaZulu-Natal Press, Pietermaritzburg, 
South Africa. 2005. Pp. 129. Price 
R165.00 (hardback). ISBN 1-86914-071-0. 
The effect of humans, especially during the past 
two centuries, on South African rangelands is 
widely manifest. Some impacts are essentially 
irreversible, although in other cases there is scope 
for rehabilitation. 
In Caring for Natural Rangelands, Ken Coetzee 
addresses some of the practical methods of 
rangeland rehabilitation in three focus areas. First, 
he describes in some detail how to manage 
eroded landscapes. Possibly the most valuable 
components here are explanations, with numerous 
illustrations, of how to ..

title: Water-use by southern Kalahari leopards : research article
authors: Jacobus du P. Bothma
abstract: Water-use by southern Kalahari leopards was studied in the southwestern part of the Kgalagadi Transfrontier Park where boreholes equipped with windmills, reservoirs and water troughs formed part of the management practice. The body fluids of prey, metabolic water and surface water formed the sources of water for these leopards, but there was no significant difference between the frequency of water-use by adult males, females without cubs, and females with cubs. Male leopards in the southern Kalahari either drank water or had access to moisture in the form of kills at known intervals of 2.7 days or 39.7 km, compared with 2.2 days and 29.4 km for females without cubs, and 1.6 days and 23.6 km for females with cubs. Succulent, wild fruits were utilized, but only infrequently so. The leopards drank borehole water that could be potentially hazardous to their health and decrease their productivity. This can have serious wildlife management implications.

title: The physical and thermal characteristics of aardwolf dens : research article
authors: Philip R. K. Richardson; Mark Anderson
abstract: The aardwolf, Proteles cristatus , is an 8-12 kg, termite-eating member of the family Hyaenidae. Aardwolves are nocturnal and spend the daylight hours in an underground den. We investigated the physical and thermal characteristics of aardwolf dens. Aardwolf dens usually had only one entrance with a single, long tunnel. It appears as if aardwolves did not dig their own burrows but enlarged the burrows of springhares. Mean temperature of the burrows was 27.2 lUg+l/Ug 02Â°C during summer and 12.2 lUg+l/Ug 1.2Â°C during winter. Daily fluctuations in den temperature were reduced compared to surface ambient temperature. This favourable, thermally-stable environment is used by aardwolves to escape the external thermal extremes, as a refuge for the rearing of young, and to evade predation from black-backed jackals and other mammalian carnivores.

title: The leopard seal at Marion Island, vagrant or seasonal transient? : : short communications
authors: M.N. Bester; G. J. Greg Hofmeyr; Stephen P. Kirkman; L.F. Chauke; P J Nico de Bruyn; S. Ferreira; Azwianewi B. Makhado; T.A.M. Maswime; Trevor McIntyre; T.W. Mulaudzi; F.M. Munyai; Pierre Pistorius; P.M. Radzilani; A.J. Ramunasi; N.H. Tshithabane; I. S. Wilkinson
abstract:
Opportunistic sightings of some 19 different leopard seals Hydrurga leptonyxl/Ig at Marion Island (46°54'S, 
37°45'E) in the South Indian Ocean were recorded 
mostly in September to October between 1980 and 
2005. Largely immature and both in poor and good 
condition, they might benefit from a locally abundant 
food resource. The species appear to be a regular 
member of the marine fauna of the region, occasionally 
hauling out on the island coastline as seasonal 
transients of the archipelago's marine environment.

title: Census techniques for southern reedbuck, Redunca arundinum , on forestry lands in the Natal Midlands, South Africa : research article
authors: R Stephen Boyes; M.R. Perrin
abstract:
Census techniques for southern reedbuck, Redunca arundinum , were tested on a forestry 
estate in the Natal Midlands, South Africa. Both transect and systematic sampling strategies 
were evaluated. Data were also collected on sex ratio and age structure. Systematic dawn 
flush counts and night habitat counts (before and after first significant frosts) were used to 
estimate minimum population size. Repeated measures ANOVA, post hocl/Ig Scheffe tests and 
coefficients of variation were used to assess the comparative repeatability of the census 
techniques. Dawn flush counts yielded very low estimates of abundance. Night habitat 
counts (before frosts) performed best of the systematic methods, obtaining highest repeatability 
and minimum population estimate. For transect counts, three enumeration and two 
estimation (computation) methods, including both modified and fixed strip width transects, 
were tested.Transect counts consistently over-estimated population size, but were relatively 
accurate and repeatable when fixed strip width (determined using the mean visibility index) 
sampling was used. This method was recommended as the transect method most suitable 
for monitoring reedbuck abundance on forestry lands in the Natal Midlands. The sex ratios 
obtained showed a bias towards females; and quantification of population structure showed 
poor repeatability and limited potential for future application.

title: Conservation status of the dwarf crag lizard, Pseudocordylus nebulosus, from the Hottentots Holland Mountains, South Africa : research article
authors: Eloise Costandius; P. le Fras N. Mouton; Charlie Boucher
abstract:
The dwarf crag lizard, Pseudocordylus nebulosus , is one of several relict ectotherm species associated with the mistbelt of the Cape Fold Mountains. Prior to this study, it was only known from a single locality in the Hottentots Holland Mountains. The extent of occurrence 
of P. nebulosusl/Ig was determined, resource partitioning among the three melanistic cordylids 
( C. oelofseni, P. capensisl/Ig and P. nebulosus ), co-occurring in this area, investigated, and the conservation status of P. nebulosusl/Ig re-evaluated. The extent of occurrence of P. nebulosusl/Ig was estimated to be only 11 km 2 . Of the three melanistic cordylids, lIgP.nebulosushasl/Ig by far the smallest range, completely overlapping the ranges of both the other two melanistic cordylids. Pseudocordylus nebulosusl/Ig was found to show a distinct affinity for surface water such as mountain streams and seepage areas. Distinct differences in resource partitioning were found among the three species regarding crevice selection, which should prevent any 
significant competition during periods of environmental stress. Although inappropriate fire management and global warming may be immediate threats to the survival of this species, 
the threats posed by the popular hiking trail in the area are probably less significant than were previously thought. It is proposed that the lIgVulnerablel/Ig status for this species be 
maintained and that the status of the species should be closely monitored. This study provides baseline data that could be used in future monitoring programmes to predict declines and fluctuations.

title: The value of community-based conservation in a heterogeneous landscape : an avian case study from sand forest in Maputaland, South Africa : research article
authors: D.G. van Eeden; Berndt J. van Rensburg; M. De Wijn; Jacobus du P. Bothma
abstract:
A local community adjacent to Tembe Elephant Park, which is the largest protected portion 
of sand forest in South Africa, recently nominated a portion of their land for a community-based natural resource management project to promote conservation in the region. The 
present study compared sand forest bird assemblages found in the communal land area with that of the Tembe Elephant Park. The communal land comprised unique avian sand forest 
assemblages, characterized by more indicator species, and higher species richness and site fidelity values than the Park. This demonstrates the biological importance of the communal land for sand forest conservation, especially from an avian perspective.

title: Adaptive herbivore ecology : from resources to populations in variable environments, by R.N. Owen-Smith : book review
authors: David L. Ward

title: Numbers of elephant seals at Prince Edward Island, Southern Ocean : short communication
authors: M.N. Bester; G. J. Greg Hofmeyr
abstract:
A rapid decline of at least 66.3% was recorded in the 
relatively small breeding population of southern 
elephant seals, Mirounga leonine , at Prince Edward 
Island between 1977 and 2004. The estimated 
number of births has declined from at least 386 to 
130 and the 2004 population size numbers 410 
(excluding pups of the year). A few tagged seals from 
neighbouring Marion Island were found to be present. 
All were immature and had hauled out for the 
pending moulting season.

title: Perceptions and consumption of game meat by a group of tourists visiting South Africa, South African Journal of Wildlife Research, 33(2) 2003 : pp.125-130 : : errata
authors: Louwrens C. Hoffman; Karlien Crafford; Magdalena Müller; De Wet Schutte

title: Lagomorph distribution across Little Karoo vegetation types : short communications
authors: H. Farmer
abstract:
With the exception of the riverine rabbit ( Bunolagus monticularis ), lagomorphs in the Karoo are regarded 
as widely distributed. Previous research has shown 
that although lagomorphs prefer grass species for 
forage, they also utilize large amounts of browse. 
Given the large variation among vegetation types 
within the Little Karoo it is unlikely that the common 
lagomorphs are as evenly distributed as assumed. 
Evidence from dung counts suggests that lagomorphs 
preferentially use grassy vegetation types and that 
dung counts are correlated with the amount of grass 
in an area.

title: Prey selection and use of natural and man-made barriers by African wild dogs while hunting : research article
authors: Ruth Rhodes; Grant Rhodes
abstract:
The hunting patterns of a pack of African wild dogs ( Lycaon pictus ) were monitored on an 
8356 ha reserve in the Waterberg Mountains, Limpopo Province, South Africa. Some 
members of the pack were radio-collared and the dogs were followed daily by researchers 
from April 2002 to January 2003. Prey selection and the use of barriers during the wild dogs' 
hunts were studied. Barriers were defined as objects such as game fences, flowing rivers 
and dams, which impeded a fleeing prey animal's escape. Kudu ( Tragelaphus strepsiceros ) 
comprised the majority (60%) of the dogs' kills, although they made up only 14% of the total 
prey items available to the dogs.Wild dogs in the reserve made 81% of their kills within 20m 
of a barrier, although these 20 m zones made up only 1.7% of the total area available to the 
dogs in the reserve. Being able to factor the use of barriers into their hunts could explain the 
preponderance of large prey in their diet. Because wild dogs make most of their kills near or 
at barriers, there are important management implications of having wild dogs in small 
reserves. These include ensuring that fences are sturdy and monitored for damage which 
might occur during hunts. The ability of wild dogs to successfully target the larger prey 
animals may also have an effect on the carnivore/prey balance and should be monitored 
carefully.

title: Use of space and habitat by elephants (Loxodonta africana) in the Maputo Elephant Reserve, Mozambique : research article
authors: Willem F. de Boer; N. Fairall; Rudi J. van Aarde; C.P. Ntumi
abstract: Satellite tracking units fitted to five elephants in the Maputo Elephant Reserve provided information on habitat use. We used the CALHOME program with Adaptive Kernel and MCP (minimum convex polygon) techniques to calculate home range sizes.We interpreted vegetation use by elephants using a vegetation map in conjunction with ArcView GIS. The home range areas (90% adaptive kernel) of cows ranged from 169-267 km 2 , while that of a bull measured 453 km 2 . The core areas (50% adaptive kernel) covered less than 6% of the reserve's area. Season did not influence home range size. Elephants did not use the available habitats randomly - the forest and Futi floodplain were preferred, while mangroves, tidal wetlands and the Maputo floodplain were seldom, if ever, used. Habitat preference was not a function of time of day.

title: Integrating landscape ecology into natural resource management by Jianguo Liu & William W. Taylor : book review
authors: Erin Bohensky
abstract:
Extracted from text ... Book review 
Integrating landscape ecology into natural 
resource management by Jianguo Liu & 
William W. Taylor. Cambridge University 
Press, Cambridge, U.K. 2002. Pp.500. Price 
?100.00 (hardback). ISBN 0521780152.

studies landscape structure, function and change', 
was born in Europe in 1939, where it remained 
until the early 1980s, as the editors recount in their 
brief introduction to this volume. Since then, the 
discipline has spread beyond Europe - to the 
United States, China, Australia and now, Africa, 
with a chapter of the field's main professional 
society, the International Association for Landscape 
Ecology, recently established ..

title: Mammalian fauna of indigenous forest in the Transkei region of South Africa : an overdue survey : research article
authors: Matt W. Hayward; Rehema M. White; Khayalethu M. Mabandla; Pakama Bukeye
abstract:
The Transkei region of the Eastern Cape has received little attention from mammalian ecologists. This paper describes the presence and absence of mammalian species in 
Afromontane, Pondoland and south coast indigenous forests using variable width transects and explores the causes of observed differences. The region maintains a rich and diverse 
mammalian fauna, although differences between forest types exist. Ungulates (bushbuck, Tragelaphus scriptusl/Ig; common duiker, Sylvicapra grimmial/Ig; and blue duiker, Cephalophus monticola ) and fossorially-foraging (bushpigs, porcupines and moles / molerats) species are relatively more abundant in south coast forests than in Afromontane or Pondoland forest 
types. This may be explained by the management practices of these nature reserves compared to state forests.

title: Sex-related variation in morphology of helmeted guineafowl (Numida meleagris) from the Riemland of the northeastern Free State, South Africa : short communication
authors: Helen Prinsloo; V. Harley; B.K. Reilly; Timothy M. Crowe
abstract:
In the hope of developing a relatively simple, nondestructive 
way of sexing adult helmeted guineafowl (Numida meleagris) , sexual differences in body 
mass and in the size of head adornments of adult 
helmeted guineafowl sampled during the winter 
months in the Riemland district of the northeastern 
Free State, South Africa, were investigated. Males 
have statistically significantly larger values for all 
attributes than do females. However, no single 
attribute, nor a combination of them, can be used to 
sex guineafowl unambiguously.

title: Erratum: Perceptions and consumption of game meat by a group of tourists visiting South Africa (South African Journal of Wildlife Research (2003) vol. 33 (2) (125-130))
authors: Louwrens C. Hoffman; K. Cradford; Magdalena Müller; De Wet Schutte

title: Sex-Specific Predation Patterns on Kudu and Impala
authors: Cornelius J. Louw; Jason P. Marshal; Hercules P. Nel; Paul J. Funston
abstract: Long-term growth rates of ungulate populations can be affected where disproportionate mortality occurs to adult females through predation. To investigate differences between lions (Panthera leo) and wild dogs (Lycaon pictus) in relative selection for female prey, we analysed ranger records for impala (Aepyceros melampus) and kudu (Strepsiceros zambesiensis) from Madikwe and Pilanesberg Nature reserves, South Africa. Each kill was categorized by sex of killed animal (female, male), likely predator (lion, wild dog) and season of kill (early wet, late wet, early dry, late dry). Our findings at Madikwe and Pilanesberg show that wild dog kill data for both kudu and impala are female-biased whereas lion kill data for the two ungulate species are male-biased.
