title: The distribution and population status of African wild dogs (Lycaon pictus) outside protected areas in South Africa : research article
authors: Peter A. Lindsey; Du Toit; M. G. L. Mills
abstract:
At present, a single viable population of endangered African wild dogs occurs in South 
Africa, in the Kruger National Park. Current conservation efforts focus on reintroducing 
wild dogs into a series of fenced reserves, thereby creating a meta-population in which 
sub-populations are actively managed to conserve genetic diversity. Additional options 
exist for conserving wild dogs outside protected areas. We report on an attempt to assess 
the numbers of wild dogs remaining outside protected areas as a precursor for conservation 
planning and show that they form a more significant component of the national population 
than previously recognized. Total numbers outside protected areas in South Africa are 
estimated to have fluctuated between 42 and 106 animals during the period 1996-2002. Of 
these, 25-67 individuals were thought to be resident outside protected areas during this 
period, with an extent of occurrence of 43 310 kmlsupg2l/supg and an area of occupancy of 17 907 km 2 . 
Sightings were most frequently reported from the western border of Kruger National Park, 
the Limpopo Valley, and northern KwaZulu-Natal. Most wild dogs occur on game ranches 
with unmodified land cover and low human densities, close to source populations. Significant 
scope for distribution expansion exists in the Limpopo and North West Provinces. 
However, efforts aimed at changing landowner attitudes towards wild dogs are necessary to 
improve the conservation status of the species outside protected areas.

title: Does Competition Shape Cheetah Prey Use Following African Wild Dog Reintroductions?
authors: Kristina L. Cornhill; Graham I. H. Kerley
abstract: Both interference and exploitative competition for prey occurs between carnivore species, which can be exacerbated if the carnivore species are of similar body size, meaning that they select for similar prey species. Studies on competition within the large carnivore guild in Africa have mainly focused on the interactions between the larger dominant (lions, Panthera leo, and spotted hyaenas, Crocuta crocuta) and smaller, submissive (cheetahs, Acinonyx jubatus, and African wild dogs, Lycoan pictus) species. However, given that cheetahs and African wild dogs are similar-sized and diurnal, they have a high overlap in dietary preference and hence scope for competition. Here, we investigate whether competition with African wild dogs shapes cheetah prey preference by comparing cheetah prey selection before and after reintroductions of African wild dogs. We show that cheetahs experienced high dietary overlap with African wild dogs but become more generalized hunters in the presence of African wild dogs. Moreover, cheetahs used three key prey species (impala, Aepyceros melampus, nyala, Tragelaphus angasii, and common duiker, Sylvicapra grimmia) differently following African wild dog reintroductions. We suggest that this reflects predominantly exploitative competition between these predators, particularly for impala. Such diet shifts may be useful indicators of resource limitations for managers conserving these two threatened small predators.

title: Seasonal Habitat Selection by Eland in an Insular Nature Reserve
authors: Jason P. Marshal; Giacomo D’Ammando; Francesca Parrini
abstract: Across southern Africa, many populations of the highly-mobile common eland (Tragelaphus oryx) are limited to small, fenced protected areas. We studied such a population at Kgaswane Mountain Reserve (KMR), South Africa, using radio-collared animals to better understand eland range use in a landscape with restricted movement. Placement of home ranges within the reserve changed from favouring woodland to dry grassland after the beginning of the wet season, while wet grassland was favoured all year. Habitat use within home ranges indicated an interaction between vegetation types and elevation that changed with season: low-elevation selection for dry grassland, open shrubland and woodland changed to selection for wet and dry grassland; high-elevation selection for open shrubland alone changed to selection for both open shrubland and woodland. Despite the fenced nature of KMR, eland appeared to have sufficiently flexible behaviour to follow landscape use and seasonal home range changes demonstrated by eland in less restrictive environments. Management activities that promote fine-scale heterogeneity and varying levels of woody cover might compensate for lack of mobility where fences limit broad-scale movements.

title: Improved Automated Recognition of Leopards from Photographs
authors: Jacobie Mouton; Lynette van Zijl; M. P. E. Schurch
abstract: Two improvements on the automated image recognition of individual leopards (Panthera pardus) are presented. Firstly, a new method of automated segmentation on images, with a guaranteed side view of the animal, allows for a region of interest to be calculated automatically, reducing the manual effort of the image processing substantially. Secondly, improvements on the automated recognition of citizen science images with extreme viewpoints are detailed.

title: Bats of southern and central Africa: a biogeographic and taxonomic synthesis – 2nd Edition
authors: Dan Parker

title: Trophy hunting in the Namibian economy : an assessment : research article
authors: Michael N. Humavindu; Jonathan I. Barnes
abstract:
Data derived from several sources were used to determine basic economic values for the 
trophy hunting industry in Namibia for the hunting season in 2000. Some 3640 trophy 
hunters spent 15 450 hunter-days, taking 13 310 game animals. Trophy hunting generated at 
least N$134 million (US$19.6 million) in direct expenditures, or gross output. Gross value 
added directly attributable to the industry was conservatively estimated at some N$63 
million (US$9.2 million). Trophy hunting constitutes at least 14% of the total tourism sector 
and is a significant component of the Namibian economy. Some 24% of the income earned in 
the trophy hunting industry accrues to poor segments of society in the form of wages and 
rentals / royalties . About 21% of income generated is captured by the government, through 
fees and taxes. Trophy hunting is an important contributor to development. More research 
on the economics of the industry is needed.

title: Notes on the social dynamics and behaviour of reintroduced lions in the Welgevonden Private Game Reserve : research article
authors: Petrus Johannes Kilian; Jacobus du P. Bothma
abstract:
We report on the social dynamics and behaviour of five lions reintroduced to the 
Welgevonden Private Game Reserve. Despite initially being together in a boma for three 
months, the lions did not stay together. Aggression was also noted after the release of a 
female, which had been placed in the boma earlier after sustaining an injury. The results 
showed different lions associating and breaking away from the group on various occasions, 
which illustrated the flexibility of lion social structure when prides are disturbed. The 
findings are similar to those observed in the Kruger National Park after a lion-cropping 
programme. The lions that were reintroduced on Welgevonden were variously related, and 
the way in which they finally associated in prides was based on their relatedness. This raised 
the question of whether association took place by chance, or whether there was some kind 
of kin-recognition in lions, resulting in them associating mostly with kin. It was not possible 
to prove kin-recognition in this study, but the association with kin could lead to genetic 
problems in the future due to inbreeding.

title: Perceptions and consumption of game meat by a group of tourists visiting South Africa : research article
authors: Louwrens C. Hoffman; Karlien Crafford; Magdalena Müller; De Wet Schutte
abstract:
The perceptions and consumption of game meat by overseas tourists visiting the Western 
Cape, South Africa, was researched by means of the survey procedure using a structured, 
self-administered questionnaire. The research group consisted of sixty tourists, most of 
whom were German and Belgian. All respondents indicated that they know game meat and 
have eaten it, while most respondents (86%) indicated that they like game meat and would 
eat it again. The respondents further indicated game meat as the meat type they most 
favoured to order in restaurants in South Africa. This provides an opportunity for the restaurant 
industry to market game meat on a larger scale. Respondents indicated that they are 
aware of the health benefits associated with game meat, but that they were not aware of any 
promotion of game meat in South Africa. Although only 10% of the respondents indicated 
that they themselves have hunted before, the culling of game animals did not concern most 
of them. Warthog was identified by the respondents as the game species that most have 
eaten in South Africa.

title: Professor Rudi Carl Bigalke (24 February 1932 - 28 November 2002) : obituary
authors: David B. Ward
abstract:
Extracted from text ... Obituary 
Professor Rudi Carl Bigalke 
(24 February 1932 - 28 November 2002) 
Professor Rudolf Carl Bigalke was a large, 
gentle man who educated generations of Stellen-bosch 
University students in the gentle art of 
nature conservation. Rudi was a biologist of the 
'old school', in the nicest sense of the term. He 
believed that nature conservationists should have 
a broad general education and that they must, 
before all else, be skilled observers of nature. He 
also believed that huntin', shootin', an' fishin'  
were integral parts of conservation - he was no 
lily-livered, tree-hugging latter-day saviour of all 
things natural. ..

title: Winter diet of frugivorous birds in the suburbs of Bloemfontein, South Africa, South African Journal of Wildlife Research, 30(4) 2000, : pp.163-165 : errata
authors: Grzegorz Kopij
abstract:
In the Short communication Kopij, G. 2000. Winter diet of frugivorous birds in the suburbs of
Bloemfontein, South Africa. S. Afr. J. Wildl. Res.l/ig 30(4): 163-165, Figs 1, 2 and 3 were inadvertently
omitted.

title: Ectoparasites of springhares in the Northern Cape Province, South Africa : research article
authors: Peggy Anderson; O. B. Kok
abstract:
The ectoparasite species of 118 Northern Cape springhares were identified and the springhare ectoparasite burdens were quantified over a 12-month period (February 1993 - January 1994). Parasite composition comprised two parasitic mite species, Hirstionyssus santos-diasil/ig and Radfordilaelaps meridionalis , one bloodsucking louse species, Eulinognathus denticulatus , one flea species, Synosternus caffer , and three ixodid tick species, Haemaphysalis pedetes, Hyalomma marginatum and Rhipicephalusl/ig sp. Mites comprised 70% of the total parasite composition, followed by lice (20%), fleas (9%) and ticks (2%). Ticks and mites were represented by larval, nymphal and adult stages. The infestation frequency of fleas was positively correlated with temperature. The mean number of ectoparasites, except for the relevant tick species, was constantly higher in male animals, while H. santos-diasil/ig and E. denticulatusl/ig infestations were significantly higher in subadult springhares. Of the total female sample, non-pregnant, post-pubertal individuals harboured the most ectoparasites (34%), followed by pregnant and lactating (19%) and pre-pubertal animals (18%). All seven ectoparasite species were present on springhares with low to average body score condition levels, while H. santos-diasil/ig and E. denticulatusl/ig mainly 
targeted animals in poor condition. Parasite-related tissue damage occurred in 25% of 253 individuals and was mainly restricted to adults.

title: Synchronous decline of populations of small antelope in a reserve in the southern Drakensberg, South Africa : research article
authors: Tim O’Connor; Sonja Krüger
abstract:
Antelope populations in Coleford Nature Reserve (1272 ha) in the southern Drakensberg 
were monitored on average 5.4 times per annum from 1986 to 2001. Population sizes of 
reedbuck ( Redunca arundinum ), mountain reedbuck ( Redunca fulvorufula ), grey rhebuck 
( Pelea capreolus ), and oribi ( Ourebia ourebi ) varied monthly because they utilized adjoining 
properties, but all first increased synchronously between 1986 and 1988 and then decreased 
synchronously until 1993. By 2002, oribi were no longer resident, while population levels of 
reedbuck, mountain reedbuck and grey rhebuck had stabilized at a lower level although the 
latter two were considered vulnerable to extirpation. The sudden, synchronous increase of 
the four species was attributed to compression of populations from adjoining properties as 
a result of an increase in hunting by dogs. Their precipitous, synchronous decline was 
attributed mainly to poaching and a succession of long, dry winters. Population recovery 
after 1993 was probably constrained by a reduction in habitat on adjoining properties and, 
for reedbuck and oribi, by increased competition from increasing populations of blesbok 
( Damaliscus dorcas phillipsii ) and wildebeest ( Connochaetes gnou ). Population declines 
were associated with reduced calving success, and in some years failure to calve. Healthy 
reedbuck populations occur on agricultural land in the region. However as the reserve is too 
small for the persistence of mountain reedbuck, grey rhebuck, and oribi they appear to 
depend on the maintenance of indigenous grassland through livestock ranching under 
private tenure.

title: Dr Richard Liversidge (17 September 1926 - 15 September 2003) : obituary
authors: Julius Koen
abstract:
Extracted from text ... Obituary 
Dr Richard Liversidge 
(17 September 1926 - 15 September 2003) 
Richard Liversidge was an enthusiastic naturalist 
interested in all aspects of nature. He had a 
keen sense of observation and interpretation of all 
living things around him. This was most probably 
instilled by his early childhood years in the southern 
African countries of Malawi (where he was 
born), Zimbabwe, Zambia and Mozambique. He 
was always willing to share his knowledge with 
other people. Through this he became mentor and 
friend to many young scientists in Kimberley. 
After graduating at the University of Cape Town 
in 1955, Richard started ..

title: Diet of Cape clawless otters in Groenvlei Lake, South Africa : : short communications
authors: LA Watson; Amy Lang
abstract:
Cape clawless otters ( Aonyx capensis ) in freshwater systems feed mainly on freshwater crabs (lIgPotamonautesl/Ig spp.). Freshwater crabs are absent from the Groenvlei Lake and the diet of clawless otters in this system is thus of interest. Analysis of otter scats from Groenvlei indicated that fish were the most important food item and that the alien fish Micropterus salmoidesl/Ig formed the bulk of the diet, followed by the alien fish Oreochromis mossambicus . Our findings indicate that although clawless otters are morphologically adapted to capture and feed on benthic prey such as crabs, they are able to subsist on fish in systems where freshwater crabs are 
absent.

title: Analysis of ovarian and adrenal activity in Namibian cheetahs : research article
authors: Karen A. Terio; Laurie Marker; E.W. Overström; Janine L. Brown
abstract:
Captive breeding of cheetahs ( Acinonyx jubatus ) has had limited success because a 
high percentage of captive females exhibit a lack of ovarian activity. This study examined 
concentrations of ovarian and adrenal hormones in wild-caught cheetahs ( n= 3) housed in 
large outdoor enclosures on private game ranches in Namibia. Cheetahs were monitored for 
a 16-month period to investigate the effect of season on ovarian and adrenal function. 
Secretory profiles of oestradiol, progestagen, and cortisol metabolites were quantified 
non-invasively using faecal steroid analysis. All three cheetahs exhibited ovarian activity; 
however, none cycled continuously. Periods of anoestrus occurred during overlapping 
periods between August and December 1994, but not during the same time period in 
1995. Mean duration of the oestrous cycle, oestrus period and baseline concentrations of 
reproductive hormones were consistent with those observed in other captive cheetah 
populations. Concentrations of faecal corticoids were lower than those from captive 
cheetahs in North America. There was no correlation between adrenal activity and ovarian 
function. Spontaneous ovulation was documented in one cheetah. These findings support 
those of earlier studies that even under natural and, therefore, presumably ideal 
environmental conditions, reproductive activity in captive cheetahs is not continuous.

title: The use of DNA microsatellite markers for determining paternity in a captive cheetah population
authors: Eric H. Harley; Ingrid Baumgarten
abstract: A litter of four cubs was born to a cheetah at the Hoedspruit Research and Breeding Centre. The identity of the father was uncertain, being either a cheetah with the king cheetah phenotype, or another with the normal phenotype. In order to determine whether the cubs could carry the king cheetah gene, microsatellite analyses were carried out using DNA primers developed originally for the domestic cat. Three out of ten sets of primers were found to give polymorphic patterns, one displaying as many as five alleles in the nine individuals studied. The results of the paternity analysis enabled the king cheetah candidate to be excluded as the parent of three of the cubs, with the other candidate showing patterns consistent with paternity for all cubs. Unlike allozymes, which show almost no variability in cheetahs, microsatellites are variable enough to provide information of value for a range of genetic studies on this species.

title: Winter diet of frugivorous birds in the suburbs of Bloemfontein, South Africa : : short communications
authors: Grzegorz Kopij
abstract: In the suburbs of Bloemfontein (South Africa), over 14 plant species produce fruits used by birds as food. Celtis africana, Ligus-trum vulgaris, Bequaertiodendron magalis-monana and Crataegus spp. provide 92% of fruit diet. Fruits are consumed mainly in June and July. The group of frugivorous birds in Bloemfontein suburbs includes a few common species, namely, redfaced mouse bird Urocolius indicus whitebacked mousebird, Colius colius, olive thrush Turdus olivaceus, redeyed bulbul pycnonotus nigricans, wattled starling Creatoph ora cinerea and Cape white-eye Zosterops pallidus.

title: Assessing the reproductive status of yellowbilled duck in the Boland, Western Cape : short communication
authors: E.E. Oettle
abstract: The reproductive status of twenty-one wild yellowbilled duck (Anas undulata) was determined from their gonadal development, from 15 May to 31 August 1997 in the Western Cape; this was compared with their behaviour just prior to capture. The first signs of gonadal stimulation were recorded in early July. Ducks from large groups showed no gonadal development, those from small groups had moderate gonadal development, while paired birds had fully developed gonads.

title: A new distribution record for the small spotted cat in the Northern Province bushveld : short communications
authors: R. John Power
abstract: Sufficient proof of a new distribution record for Felis nigripes is reported, based on three visual observations made during September 1998. The locality of the observations was in the Madjuma Lion Reserve, Mabula Game Reserve, NorthernProvince (240o 44' S, 27o 58' E) in Mixed Bushveld. The microhabitat was on old lands comprised of short Cynodon dactylon - grassland with a sparse cover of Acacia tortilis. The habitat physiognomy was in fact regarded as optimal in the context of the most recent study in the Kimberley area.

title: Through the Eyes of the Protectors: Field Rangers' Mental Models as a Conservation Management Tool in the 21st Century
authors: Riechelle Prinsloo; Engela P. de Crom; Xander Combrink
abstract: African Journal of Wildlife Research is a multidisciplinary journal that has been published since 1971 and covers the scientific, applied, managerial, methodological, and sociological issues related to wildlife research.

title: The Shortfall of Using Locality Records in the Conservation Planning of South African Cavernicolous Bats: The Natal Long-Fingered Bat as a Case Study
authors: Mariëtte Pretorius; Mark Keith
abstract: African Journal of Wildlife Research is a multidisciplinary journal that has been published since 1971 and covers the scientific, applied, managerial, methodological, and sociological issues related to wildlife research.

title: Aquaculture: a substitute for management of living marine resources?
authors: A.E.F. Heydoorn
abstract: Concern over declining yields in stocks of the living exploitable resources of the sea in various parts of the world has stimulated wide interest in aquaculture. Marine animals which have been cultivated artificially can be divided into three categories: carnivores, herbivores and filter feeders. The basic methods employed in the cultivation of animals in these three categories are reviewed. Progress made in several countries in aquaculture techniques is illustrated but mention is also made of various problems which have been encountered. On this basis the potential of marine aquaculture in South Africa is considered, taking the geomorphology of our coastline, climatic conditions, the types of animals available as well as marketing outlets, into account. The conclusion is reached that research in this direction is well worthwhile but that it is unlikely that aquaculture will replace the need for sound management of natural resources in the near future.

title: Management for greywing and redwing francolins in Natak
authors: R.C. Mentis; Moritz Bigalke
abstract: A study was carried out to acquire data on the ecology of greywing and redwing francolins, ascertain reasons for alleged declines, provide a basis for sound advice to landowners interested in conserving these birds, and to provide information for preparation of management plans for state and provincially administered land in midland and highland Natal. Results of the study, only summarised in this paper, indicated both francolins to be animals of fire-climax grasslands. Factors limiting stocks of these birds appeared to concern density of cover, quality' and quantity of food, and possibly social behaviour. Recommendations made for habitat management for the two francolins concern management of plant succession by use of fire, control of interspersion of burnt and unburnt areas of grassland, and compensating on farmland for reduction in natural control of interspersion of burnt and unburnt areas of grassland, and compensating on farmland for reduction in natural redwing habitat, as a result of farming practices, through provision of extra food and cover on small, strategically situated areas.

title: Seroprevalence of Toxoplasma gondii in free-ranging lion and leopard populations in southern Africa : short communications
authors: B.L. Penzhorn; E. Stylianides; M. Van Vuuren; Kathleen A. Alexander; D.G.A. Meltzer; Norman L. Mukarati
abstract:
Antibodies to Toxoplasma gondiil/ig were detected in 92% 
of 53 sera from lions from Botswana, in 100% of 21 sera 
from Zimbabwe, in 100% of 12 sera from Kruger National 
Park and 100% of 30 sera from Hluhluwe-Umfolozi Park, 
South Africa. The single leopard serum from Botswana 
was positive, while 86% of 7 leopard sera from Kruger 
National Park were positive. Clinical implications of T. 
gondiil/ig infection in free-ranging non-domestic felids are 
unknown.

title: New distributional records for three microchiropteran bats (Vespertillionidae, Rhinolophidae) from the Free State Province, South Africa : short communication
authors: Jessica Watson
abstract: Distributional data on three microchiropteran species (Myotis lesueuri (Roberts, 1919), Eptesicus hottentotus (A. Smith, 1833) and Rhinolophus denti Thomas, 1904), recorded in the Free State Province for first time, are presented. In all three cases these comprise range extensions for the species.

title: The distribution and seasonal changes of louse populations on impala Aepyceros melampus : : short communication
authors: Sonja Matthee; I Horák; D.G.A. Meltzer
abstract: Five louse species were collected from the hides of 45 impala ewes Aepyceros melampus examined in sets of 15 during three sampling periods in the Northern Province, South Africa. These were Damalinia aepycerus, Damalinia elongata, Linognathus aepycerus, Linognathus nevilli and an unidentified Linognathus sp. The aims of the study were to determine whether lice infesting impala exhibit preferences for specific sites on the host's body and also to determine the role of season in louse abundance. D.aepycerus was predominantly present on the body and tail. L.aepycerus showed no distinct distribution pattern and L.nevilli was most abundant on the hind feet.

title: Lions and leopards as game ranch animals, J. van Heerden (ed) : proceedings reviews
authors: P.I. Funston
abstract: Predators, in general, are a contentious topic in the game ranching industry and as a rule have been viewed as undesirable and counter productive in terms of game ranching. Increasingly, however, ecotourist pressure and the increasing number of larger cooperative areas under wildlife have created the opportunity to reintroduce specifically lions to various areas. Leopards have been present in most areas of thecountry and are by and large part of even certain agricultural areas but their very nature limits their contact with man to the occasional conflict.

title: The smaller mammals of KwaZulu-Natal, Peter Taylor : book review
authors: Gary N. Bronner
abstract: This is the first authoritative scientific text on the taxonomy, biogeography and ecology of the smaller mammal species in KwaZulu-Natal, and complements two previous publications (published by Dave Rowe-Rowe in 1992 and 1994) to form a complete series for the mammals of the province. It contains little new scientific information beyond updated distribution records and taxonomic treatments, and is essentially a comprehensive review of previously published findings.

title: Surgical anaesthesia in a week-old springbok - a case report : : short communication
authors: G.F. Stegmann; Brendan Tindall
abstract: Anaesthesia was required in an one-week old, bottle-fed springbok lamb (Antidorcas marsupialis) for surgical repair of a luxated coxo-femoral joint. Springbok are known to be susceptible to capture myopathy. Minimal physical restraint was required for venepuncture. Anaesthesia was induced after the intravenous injection of 3 mg / kg midazolam hydrochloride and 4 mg / kg ketamine hydrochloride, and maintained with halothane in oxygen on a circle-breathing circuit. Anaesthetic depth and cardiopulmonary variables weremonitored using reflexes and multi-parameter physiological monitors. The ventilation rate varied between 20-24 breaths / min, and the end-tidal CO2 concentration between 9.2 and 11.3%. The heart rate decreased from 148 beats / min before induction to a rate that varied between 132 and 96 during maintenance of anaesthesia. The mean arterial blood pressure varied between 7.7 and 9.1 kPa during maintenance. Body temperature decreased from 38.6oC before induction to 35.4oC at the end of surgery. Apart from the ketamine-induced involuntary movements of the neck and limbs, which disappeared after the dose of midazolam was increased, no adverse effects were seen from the anaesthetic agents. Recovery from anaesthesia and surgery was uneventful.

title: Immobilisation of the giant canerat Thryonomys swinderianus with ketamine hydrochloride : : short communications
authors: G.F. Stegmann
abstract: Ketamine hydrochloride was used for the immobilisation of a litter of four giant canerats Thryonomys swinderianus. The animals were immobilised for radiological purposes every two weeks extending over a period of 22 weeks as part of a radiological study. Ketamine was initially administered intramuscularly at a dose of 20 mg / kg. Additional ketamine was administered when movement occurred during radiological positioning. A mean dose of 24.7 mg / kg was calculated from the total dose of ketamine administered to all the animals over the period of radiological investigation. Intramuscular administration of ketamine provided a fast induction time of not more than 3 min; short-term immobilisation with sufficient muscle relaxation to provide for radiological positioning without movement. Palpebral and pedal reflexes remained intact during immobilisation indicating that only a light plane of surgical anaesthesia was obtained. Recovery time to regain sternal recumbency varied between 11 and 35 min. Unwanted side effects such as muscle rigidity or epileptiform convulsions were not observed during this investigation.

title: Fentanyl citrate for the immobilization of oribi
authors: P .C. Viljoen
abstract: A technique for the capture of free-ranging oribi using a combination of fentanyl and xylazine is descriptionbed. Based on the results obtained from 11 successful immobilizations a dosage rate of 0.4 mg/kg fentanyl and 1,1 mg/kg xylazine is recommended. No mortalities occurred.

title: Food ofthe Redbilled Teal in Rhodesia
authors: P. F. Woodall
abstract: The food of the red billed teal at three localities in Rhodesia is descriptionbed from 108 gizzard contents. Three categories were identified: seeds and fruits (Polygonum, Potamogeton, Cyperaceae and Gramineae); other plant material; and animals (Annelida, Insecta, Arachnida and Mollusca). At the end of the dry season (October), i?½other plant materiali?½ predominated in the gizzards, while teal in reproductive condition (December) showed an increased frequency of animals in the diet. A high frequency of oligochaete cocoons and Chironomidae larvae was characteristic of samples from one locality.

title: Wildplaasbestuur, J. du P. Bothma (Ed.) : book review
authors: R.C. Bigalke
abstract: This new edition of a book that first appeared in 1986 is a paperback with a double column layout, 14 colour plates and 159 figures. It is the work of 27 collaborators and has been updated and considerably expanded, accommodationg much more text than the first edition in about the same number of pages. In his introduction, professor Bothma describes the book as a coordinated effort to summarise available knowledge on game ranch management in the form of a practical handbook for farmers, managers, consultants and students.

title: Lack of allozyme heterogeneity at eight loci studied in a roan antelope Hippotragus equinus population from the Percy Fyfe Nature Reserve : short communication
authors: J. Paul Grobler; G.P. Nel
abstract: Protein gel-electrophoresis was used to assess genetic diversity in an isolated roan antelope Hippotragus equinus population. No allelic polymorphism was detected at loci previously identified as polymorphic in this species and in other species of the subfamily Hippotraginae. The possible contribution of recent management record and historic events to the present lack of heterogeneity are discussed.

title: Diets and food preferences of two South African tortoises : the implications for niche separation : research review
authors: Adrian Hailey
abstract: Southern Africa has the most diverse tortoise fauna in the world (Swingland & Klemens 1989). The possibility of inter-specific competition is therefore clearly of interest. Sympatric Mediterranean tortoises, for example, are largely separated by habitat (Wright, Steer & Hailey 1988).

title: The dingo in Australia and Asia, Laurie Corbett : book review
authors: I.S. Wilkinson
abstract: This work emanates from the studies by the author, Laurie Corbett, and other dingo researchers over the past three decades. The easy writing style, and explanations of scientific concepts in boxes throughout the text, combined with scientific accuracy and thought-provoking conclusions, provide natural historian and scientist alike with an excellent account of the ecological role of the dingo.

title: Southern African Wildlife Management Association Conference on the Sustainable Use of Wildlife : 9-11 April 1996 : : conference report
authors: R.M. Little
abstract: The potentials, concerns and conflicts relating to wildlife resource use were thoroughly addressed at a conference titled 'Sustainable Use of Wildlife' organised by the Southern African Wildlife Management Association (WMA) and hosted by the Percy FitzPatrick Institute, University of Cape Town, from 9-11 April 1996. The aim of the conference was to integrate cross-disciplinary and cross-institutional wisdom and opinions into a three day working session on key issues related to the sustainability, potentials and marketing of wildlife use in Africa.

title: An oesophageal fistulation technique for impala: Short communication
authors: H.H. Visser; Pietersen; Spreeth; E.B. Meissner
abstract: An oesophageal fistulation procedure is descriptionbed for impala Aepyceros melampus. The cannula is inserted ventral to the m. cleidomastoideus and dorsal to the m. sternomandibularis approximately in the middle of the neck lateral to the linea mediana ventralis where the oesophagus is closest to the skin. Less tissue is therefore trapped between cannula and skin, thus reducing the incidence of pressure necrosis and facilitating neck movement.

title: A method of skull-based sex determination of elephant carcasses: Short communication
authors: P.J. Viljoen
abstract: A method for determining the sex of elephant remains from skulls is descriptionbed. Significant sexual dimorphism was demonstrated in mandible width for elephants of known age and sex, older than 15 years. Mandible width at a given age appears to be a valid field method for sexing decomposed carcasses of older elephants.

title: Preliminary feeding data on red-billed teal, Cape teal and Cape shoveller at Barberspan: Short communications
authors: Randall J. Mitchell
abstract: Food organisms found in the oesophagus of red-billed teal Anas erythrorhyncha, Cape shoveller Anas smithii and Cape teal Anas capensis collected at Barberspan in the Transvaal are descriptionbed and the differences between the different species are discussed.

title: A note on the immobilization of serval Felis serval with ketamine and acetylpromazine: Short communication
authors: P.B. Rowe-Rowe; D.T. Lowry
abstract: Two adult male serval Felis serval were caught in padded steel-jawed leg-hold traps which had been set for the live capture of black-backed jackals Canis mesomelas. The serval were immobilized with a combination of ketamine hydrochloride (Ketalar, Parke Davis) and acetylpromazine (Boots) so that they could be removed from the traps

title: The Springbok, J.D. Skinner & G.N. Louw : book review
authors: N. Fairall
abstract: Though produced as a very nice little hardcover book complete with a striking dust cover, this is essentially a monograph which, as the cover blurb puts it, is a review of the literature on this truly South African antelope.

title: Baboon capture and factors influencing capture success in the Western Cape Province, South Africa
authors: D. J. Brand
abstract:
The efficiency of cage traps and factors influencing the capture results of chacma baboons Papio ursinus were investigated in the Western Cape Province. During a four-year study at eight different sites, baboons were captured using cage traps. This study suggested that cage traps were effective in capturing baboons. Cage traps covered with a wire mesh (size = 25 mm) and equipped with trap door locking mechanisms, were more effective than traps not complying with these requirements. Furthermore, the success of cage traps in capturing baboons was influenced positively by conditioning troop members to feed at trap sites during the baiting phase, by using firm bait during trapping, and by trapping under fine weather conditions.
Die effektiwiteit van vanghokke en faktore wat die vangresultate van bobbejane Papio ursinus beinvloed, is ondersoek in die Wes-Kaapprovinsie. Gedurende 'n vierjaarstudie op agt verskillende lokaliteite, is bobbejane met vanghokke gevang. Hierdie studie het aangedui dat vanghokke effektiewe bobbejaanvangapparate is. Vanghokke met 'n maasdraadbedekking (grootte = 25 mm) en toegerus met valdeursluitmeganismes, was meer effektief as hokke wat nie aan hierdie vereistes voldoen het nie. Verder, word die sukses van bobbejaanvanghokke positief beinvloed deur troplede gedurende die aanlokfase te kondisioneer om by vangplekke te vreet, deur ferm lokaas gedurende die vangfase te gebruik, en deur in mooiweerstoestande te vang.

title: The Mammals of the Southern African Subregion, J.D. Skinner and R.H.N. Smithers : book review
authors: D.T. Rowe-Rowe
abstract:
This is a partly revised, expanded, and updated edition of the original book by Smithers (1983).
The text is comprehensive, containing detailed information on taxonomy, descriptions, measurements, distribution, habitat, habits, food, and reproduction of the 338 mammals that occur in southern Africa. The 1990 edition exceeds the 1983 edition by 45 pages in text length, and the original 30 colour plates have been replaced with 38 new plates by artist Dick Findlay. For most of the species the text has been expanded by the addition of new information and references, and in the instances of a number of other mammals (e.g. the rhinos), the text has been extensively revised. In total over 1100 new references have been incorporated.

title: Physiological changes related to nutritional status in boma-confined impala
authors: C.M. Knox; J. Hattingh; Jacobus P. Raath
abstract:
Body mass, plasma total lipid concentration, plasma urea nitrogen and kidney fat, bane marrow and adrenal indices were measured in impala (Aepyceros melampas melampus) subjected to boma-confinement and repeated capture in nets (experimental group), and also in free-ranging impala (control group). Kidney fat and bone marrow indices were significantly lower and adrenal indices higher in the experimental group after four weeks of confinement compared with values obtained in control impala. Body mass and plasma total lipid concentration decreased while plasma urea nitrogen concentration increased over the confinement period in the experimental group. These physiological changes indicate that mobilization of fat reserves accompanied by a change in nutritional status occurred in these animals probably as a result of reduced food intake and physiological stress associated with boma-confinement and repeated capture in nets.
Liggaamsmassa, plasma totale lipide-konsentrasie, plasma-ureumstikstof en niervet-, beenmurg- en adrenale indekse vir rooibokke (Aepyceros melampus melampus) onderworpe aan boma-aanhouding en herhaalde vangs in nette (eksperimentele groep), sowel as vir vrylewende rooibakke (kontrolegroep) is bepaal. Niervet en beenmurgindekse was betekenisvol laer en adrenale indekse hoer vir die eksperimentele groep na vier weke van aanhouding in vergelyking met waardes verkry vir die kontrolegroep. 'n Toenemende afname in liggaamsmassa en plasma totale lipide-konsentrasie is oor die tydperk van aanhouding waargeneem. Plasma-ureumstikstofkonsentrasie in die eksperimentele groep het 'n styging getoon in vergelyking met waardes verkry tydens immobilisasie en met die kontrolegroep. Die fisiologiese veranderinge in die diere toon dat mobilisasie van vetreserwes met veranderinge in voedingstatus plaasgevind het, waarskynlik as gevolg van 'n afname in voedselinname en fisiologiese spanning te wyte aan boma-aanhouding en herhaalde vangs in nette.

title: The sable antelope as a game ranch animal : book review
authors: Jacobus du P. Bothma
abstract: The publication includes 25 papers and starts with a review of the extinct bloubok, relative of the sable antelope and the roan antelope. This paper by B.L. Penzhorn details the available historical evidence and discusses some causes for the bloubok's extinction. This is followed by an Afrikaans paper on the status, distribution and management of both the sable antelope and the roan antelope in the Transvaal by E.C. Nel. In this paper a number of limiting factors for these two ungulate types are addressed and the new conservation approach for them in the Transvaal is outlined.

title: Isolation of Aegyptianella sp. (Rickettsiales: Anaplasmataceae) from helmeted guineafowls in the Kruger National Park
authors: F. W. Huchzermeyer; Ivan G. Horak; Leo Braack
abstract:
Three isolates of an Aegyptianella sp. were established in young guineafowls experimentally infected with blood collected from wild helmeted guineafowls in the Skukuza area of the Kruger National Park. The parasite was unable to infect turkeys and domestic fowls. In addition to ring and spherical forms typical of Aegyptianella pullorum, the organism also exhibited numerous irregularly shaped forms. Because of its inability to infect domestic fowls and morphological differences the organism is considered to be a species distinct from A. pullorum. Argasid larvae found on the wild guineafowls were not Argas walkerae.
Drie isolate van 'n Aegyptianella sp. is in jong tarentale wat eksperimenteel met die bloed van wilde tarentale vanaf die Skukuza-gebied van die Nasionale Kruger-Wildtuin ingespuit is, gevestig. Dit was nie moontlik om kalkoene of hoenders met die parasiet te besmet nie. Bykomstig tot die ring- en sfeerfatsoene wat tipies is van Aegyptianella pullorum, het die organisme ook as veelvuldige onreelmatige vorms voorgekom. Omdat die organisme nie hoenders kon besmet nie en weens morfologiese verskille, blyk dit 'n spesie anders as A. pullorum te wees. Tampanlarwes op die wilde tarentale was nie die van Argas walkerae nie.

title: Laboratory studies on the food intake of six surf-zone fish species
authors: H.H. Du Preez; A. McLachlan; J.F.K. Marais; A. C. Cockcroft; W. J. Strydom; Ian Davidson
abstract:
Food intake of Lithognathus lithognathus, Lithognathus mormyrus, Pomadasys commersonnii, Lichia amia, Myliobatus aquila and Rhinobatos annulatus was determined under controlled laboratory conditions. Daily fluctuations in energy intake were observed, with a period of high intake being followed by a period of lower intake. Individual fish consumed 0 - 45% of body weight per day, which was within the range recorded for other species. Daily food intake (dry weight or energy) was affected by fish weight and could be described by the model: Food intake = a (live body weight)b. Energy intake of the fish was the highest when they were fed twice a day or when food was continuously available. Energy intake of individual fish was higher when eitherDonax serra or Liza richardsonii was fed than when Macropetasma africanus was fed. Energy intake of all the species (except that of R. annulatus) was significantly influenced by temperature and was generally higher at 20°C than at 15°C. The relevance of these findings is discussed.
Die voedselinname van Lithognathus lithognathus, Lithognathus mormyrus, Pomadasys commersonnii, Lichia amia, Myliobatus aquila en Rhinobatos annulatus is onder beheerde laboratoriumtoestande bepaal. Daaglikse fluksiasies in energie-inname is waargeneem. 'n Periode van hoe inname is deur 'n laer inname periode gevolg. Individuele visse het 0 - 45% van hul lewende gewig per dag geeet. Soortgelyke inname waardes is vir ander spesies waargeneem. Daaglikse voedselinname (droe massa of energie) is deur die massa van die visse beinvloed en is deur die vergelyking: Voedselinname = a (lewende liggaamsmassa)b beskryf. Gedurende die eksperimentele periode was die energie-inname van visse wat Donax serra of Liza richardsonii gevoer is, hoer as die van visse wat Macropetasma africanus gevoer is. Temperatuur het die energie-inname van al die spesies beduidend beinvloed (behalwe die van Rhinobatus annulatus) en was hoer by 20°C as by 15°C. Die toepaslikheid van die bevindinge word bespreek.

title: Diet of two small Barbus spp. in a subtropical South African impoundment
authors: L. Polling; H. J. Schoonbee; J.E. Saayman
abstract:
Investigations were made into the feeding habits of two small cyprinids, Barbus paludinosus and B. unitaeniatus, collected from a subtropical impoundment in the Transvaal, South Africa. A brief description is given of the environmental conditions which prevailed during the study. Results suggest that B. paludinosus feeds mainly in midwater whereas B. unitaeniatus appears to be more of a benthic feeder. Both species are opportunistic feeders, eating significant quantities of plant material.
'n Ondersoek na die eetgewoontes van twee gieliemientjies, Barbus paludinosus and B. unitaeniatus, wat in 'n subtropiese dam in Transvaal, Suid-Afrika versamel is, is gedoen. Resultate dui daarop dat B. paludinosus oorwegend sooplanktonorganismes eet terwyl B. unitaeniatus meer van bentiese organismes gebruik naaak. Beide spesies voed opportunisties en neem redelike hoeveelhede plantaardige materiaal in. 'n Opsomming van die omgewingsfaktoregedurende die ondersoek is ingesluit.

title: Clutch sizes ducks in the south-western Cape
authors: C.W. Hey
abstract:
Clutch-size data for 13 duck species collected by Cape Nature Conservation in the south-western Cape over a period of more than two decades are presented. Significant differences were recorded in the mean clutch sizes of the Cape teal Anas capensis and Cape shoveller A. smithii for the breeding season, although the observed variability was low. Clutch sizes also varied between different water bodies.
Inligting oor die broeiselgroottes van 13 eendsoorte wat deur Kaaplandse Natuurbewaring in die suidwes-Kaap oor meer as twee dekades ingesamel is, word aangebied. Betekenisvolle verskille is aangeteken in die gemiddelde broeiselgroottes vir die teeleend Anas capensis en Kaapse slopeend A. smithii oor die broeiseisoen, alhoewel die verskille gering was. Broeiselgroottes het ook tussen verskillende waterliggame gewissel.

title: Aspects of the chemical control of Xenopus laevis tadpoles under laboratory conditions
authors: J. Theron; Louwrens C. Hoffman; J. F. Prinsloo
abstract:
The chemical control of Xenopus laevis tadpoles, under laboratory conditions, was tested using different concentrations of chlorine. Simultaneously, the toxicity of chlorine to Clarias gariepinus juveniles was investigated. X. laevis was more sensitive to chlorine concentrations, with 100% mortality occurring at 0,5 mg/l (tap water) and 12,0 mg/l (pond water and acidified pond water), whilst for C. gariepinus juveniles, this only occurred at 5,0 mg/l (tap water) and 12,0 mg/l (pond water and acidified pond water), respectively. The residual toxicity of chlorine sharply decreased after 72 h.
Die chemiese beheer van Xenopus laevis paddavisse is met behulp van verskillende konsentrasies chloor onder laboratoriumtoestande vasgestel. Terselfdertyd is die toksisiteit van chloor vir jongvis van Clarias gariepinus bepaal. X. laevis was meer sensistief vir chloor, met 100% mortaliteite by 0,5 mg/l (kraanwater) en 12,0 mg/l (dam- en aangesuurde damwater) as C. gariepinus jongvis, waar onderskeidelik 5,0 mg/l (kraanwater) en 12,0 mg/l (dam- en aangesuurde damwater) daarvoor benodig was. Die residuele toksisiteit van die chloor het drasties verminder na 72 h.

title: The African elephant as a game animal : book review
authors: Jacobus du P. Bothma
abstract:
It is a sign of the immense progress of game ranching in South Africa that elephants and both types of rhinoceros are increasingly being re-established on game ranches. Yet these animals must be regarded as special groups for which individual guidelines are necessary in the game ranching context.
The work under review is aimed at filling such a need for the African elephant. The work, which contains many useful contributions from a variety of authors, actually is the Proceedings of a symposium on the African elephant as a game ranch animal, which took place at Berg-en-Dal in the Kruger National Park from 29-30 April 1991.

title: Optimizing stocking mix, financial resources for game production
authors: RL Davies
abstract:
Most game ranches have several game species whose abundance is self regulated. This often leads to competition between species, and species with a low financial return usually predominate. By optimizing the productive ability of the game species as well as their financial return and demand on resources, an ecological and economic stocking mix can be determined. This paper describes linear programming and how this objective can be achieved using this approach.
Die meeste wildplase het verskeie wildspesies waarvan die getalle op 'n natuurlike manier beheer word. Daar is dus kompetisie tussen spesies en die wat die laagste profyt toon is gewoonlik die oorheersende spesie. Deur die wildspesies se optimale produktiewe vermoe, finansiele opbrengs en verbruik van hulpbronne te bepaal met behulp van 'n lineere programmeringstegnlek, kan 'n ekologiese en ekonomiese wildbeladingsverhouding bepaal word.

title: Capture Care and Management of Threatened Mammals : book review
authors: N. Fairall
abstract: This volume is the proceedings of an international meeting held at Skukuza in the Kruger National Park during September 1993.

title: Die versorging en ontwikkeling van Suid-Afrikaanse krimpvarkies in aanhouding
authors: Ceyda Kök; O.B. Van Ee
abstract: The successful care of eight new-born South African hedgehogs Atelerix frontalis on a farm in the eastern Orange Free State, is descriptionbed. Individual body mass was considerably higher than is hitherto known in the literature. Up to and during the first hibernation, which lasted approximately three months, males were generally heavier than females. Both sexes experienced a mass loss of approximately 15% while hibernating. Females can become gravid during their first year of life so that parturition takes place during the favourable summer conditions.

title: Observations on reproduction and morphometries of scrub hares in the Kruger National Park
authors: B.L. Penzhorn; Ivan G. Horak; Andrea Spickett; Leo Braack
abstract:
Linear measurements and body masses of various body parts of scrub hares Lepus saxatilis were recorded during an intensive investigation into the role of these hares as hosts of ixodid ticks in the Kruger National Park. There was a preponderance of males in the sample. Body length (excluding tail), body mass and eviscerated carcass mass of females were significantly greater than those of males. Perinephric fat mass showed distinct seasonality, reaching a peak in July and August in males, and peaking in August and September in females. Reproduction was aseasonal; 85,1% of adult females were gravid, lactating, or both gravid and lactating. Mean litter size was 1,87 and mean birth mass 115 g.
Lengte-afmetings en massas van verskeie liggaamsdele van kolhase Lepus saxatilis is versamel tydens 'n intensiewe ondersoek na die rol van hierdie hase as gashere van skildbosluise in die Nasionale Krugerwildtuin. Die monster het oorwegend uit mannetjies bestaan. Liggaamslengte (stert uitgesluit), liggaamsmassa en ontweide karkasmassa van wyfies was betekenisvol groter as die van mannetjies. Niervetmassa het seisoenaal gewissel; by die mannetjies was die piek in Julie en Augustus en by die wyfies in Augustus en September. Voortplanting was nie-seisoenaal; 85,1% van die volwasse wyfies was dragtig, lakterend, of dragtig en lakterend. Gemiddelde werpselgrootte was 1,87 en gemiddelde geboortemassa 115 g.

title: Game ranch management edited by J. du P. Bothma
authors: D.T. Rowe-Rowe

title: Tick-induced paralysis and mortality of gemsbok
authors: South África; Bloemfontein
abstract: The diet of crowned plovers Vanellus coronatus in open grassland at the J.B.M. Hertzog Airport at Bloemfontein consists mainly of animal matter of which insects are most important. Based on the frequency of occurrence, Coleoptera, Isoptera and Hymenoptera are most often taken but, according to the dry-mass composition, the Isoptera, specifically the harvester termite Hodotermes mossambicus, is the most important food source. No significant difference occurs in the overall diet of males and females. Seasonal variation in the stomach-content mass is probably related to breeding activities. The average mass of the stomach content of both sexes is significantly higher in the afternoon than in the early morning.

title: Trichomonas gallinae in wild raptors on the Cape Peninsula : short communication
authors: D. Pepler; E.E. Oettle
abstract:
An outbreak of avian trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas gallinae occurred on the Cape Peninsula and surrounds in seven species of diurnal and nocturnal birds of prey. The virulence of the parasite appears to be different from that reported in the northern hemisphere. It is suggested that this disease might negatively affect the reproductive success of certain species. A survey of the epidemiology of Trichomonas gallinae in the families Columbidae, Falconidae and Strigidae will illuminate its potential to affect the viability of future populations.
'n Uitbraak van trichomoniase veroorsaak deur Trichomonas gallinae het in die Kaapse Skiereiland en omliggende gebiede voorgekom, en sewe spesies van dag- en naglewende roofvoels is aangetas. Die virulensie van die parasiet blykbaar anders as die wat in die noordelike halfrond gerapporteer is. Daar word voorgestel dat hierdie siekte voortplantingsukses van sekere spesies negatief mag beinvloed. 'n Opname van die epidemiologie van Trichomonas gallinae in die families Columbidae, Falconidae en Strigidae sal lig werp op die parasiet se potensiaal om die lewensvatbaarheid van toekomstige populasies te beinvloed.

title: A method for capturing the red rock rabit Pronolagus rupestris: Short communication
authors: D. Pepler
abstract: Red rock rabbits were captured at one locality in the Cape Province. The animals were blinded with quartz-halogen torches and caught in a trout landing net. The effects of weather and ambient light conditions on capture success are discussed.

title: The Imperial Lion: Human dimensions of wildlife management in central Africa by Stuart Marks: Book review
authors: United Kingdom Trendrine; Zennor; St Ives; Cornwall; Tr Bw

title: Some data on the reproductive biology of the rock hyrax
authors: M.R. Fourie; Louise Perrin
abstract: This paper reports on several aspects of the reproduction of a rock hyrax Procavia capensis population in the Mountain Zebra National park. The male hyrax commonly attains sexual maturity at 28 to 29 months of age. Females generally reach puberty at 16 to 17 months of age. One of the 72 females less than a year old, attained precocious puberty at four to five months of age. Middle-aged hyrax (between two and eight years) have significantly larger litter sizes than do young (less than two years) and old hyrax (older than eight years). The mean prenatal litter size for 95 hyrax of various ages was 2,65. Ova or prenatal loss occurred in 23% of the females investigated and accounted for an 8% loss in ova or embryos. Weaning takes place at one to four months of age with a mean value of 2,3 months.

title: A technique to determine leaf cover of dicotyledonous plants
authors: P.J. Birkenstock
abstract: A method of determining a total leaf-cover index for dicotyledons in different height classes using a visual leaf area estimation technique that is quick and easy to use and seems to show good inter- and intra-observer reliability is descriptionbed. Values are expressed in cm2m-3 or as percentages for each height class and a 'leaf-cover profile' for the area sampled can be drawn up to give a pictorial presentation of the quantity of leaf matter present.

title: New records of occurrences for six species of small mammals in the northern Cape Province
authors: I.L. Erasmus; S.H. Rautenbach
abstract: The occurrence of two rodent species (Steatomys krebsii and Dendromus melanotis) and four species of bats (Scotophilus dinganii, Hipposideros caffer, Taphozous mauritianus and Rhinolophus darlingi) is recorded in the northern Cape Province for the first time. The difficulties in positively identifying R. darlingi specimens necessitated a karyological overview and morphometric multivariate analyses of selected representatives of the ten southern African species of Rhinolophus.

title: Reproductive parameters from hand-reared springbok Antidorcas marsupialis: Short communication
authors: P.J. Birkenstock
abstract: Data from hand-reared springbok indicate an oestrus cycle of 16 (14 -17) days, and an anoestrus period in February. Ewes are covered 9 days after lambing. Accurate gestation periods of 174 and 180 days occurred. Weaning was found to occur at 120 -122 days. Young ewes conceived at the age of 43 and 44 weeks. The ram first mated at the age of 24 months and it chased out young rams of 54 weeks of age from the mixed herds.
